title: No spending boost in RBA rate cuts
text:
Mr Wilson said the data clearly showed he theory that RBA rate cuts led to a significant increase in consumer spending was false.

“Every time the RBA reduces rates the flow through isn’t being felt as widely as some might expect in consumers' hip pockets," he said.

“This data is timely and should further prompt the RBA to press pause on further rate cuts without hard evidence of their efficacy, and especially should lead to questioning the efficacy of quantitative easing.”

The RBA has cut the cash rate three times since June by a total of 75 basis points, with about 60 per cent being passed on by the big banks.

RBA governor Philip Lowe has said looser monetary policy works through two ways: putting downward pressure on the exchange rate, and boosting household income because they have twice as much debt as deposits.

RBA officials have argued that even if people use lower rates to pay off debt, at some point the extra money gets spent and helps the economy.

"There is uncertainty about how much of that cash flow boost will be spent or saved, including in the form of paying down mortgages faster," RBA deputy governor Guy Debelle said in August.

"If households use the additional cash flow to pay down their mortgages, it does bring closer the date that they will be more comfortable with their balance sheets and return to more regular spending habits."

In a similar vein, Treasury secretary Steven Kennedy told a Senate committee last week that even if the government's personal income tax cuts were used to pay off debt faster, "this will still bring forward the point at which households could increase their spending".

The CBA data focuses on the $249 billion in outstanding variable principal and interest balance at the bank, which represents 66 per cent of its $379 billion mortgage book.

About 20 per cent of CBA home loans charge fixed rates and the remaining 14 per cent are interest-only mortgages with variable rates.
description: Only 7 per cent of borrowers at the country's largest home lender reduce their monthly mortgage repayments after an interest rate cut.
